Sourced Statements: “With all the struggling I was doing, my attitude took a hit,” Kahlia said. “The more you witness yourself being down and out, the more you feel down and out, and the more stuck you feel.”
Source Justification: Her health deteriorated and visits to doctors drained her savings. Recently she decided to start a business performing social justice songs at events. But with no extra funds or time, she had to pause the venture.

Sourced Statements: The pilot program will allow researchers to track its impact in a large, diverse region, said Sean Kline, director of the Stanford Basic Income Lab, which studies guaranteed income programs across the country.
Source Justification: director of the Stanford Basic Income Lab. Which studies guaranteed income programs across the country.

Sourced Statements: “Whenever L.A. city or county or Chicago or New York do something bold like this, it’s a really important signal that this big policy idea found its footing during COVID and represents a possible way forward in terms of supporting low income people across America,” Kline said.
Source Justification: director of the Stanford Basic Income Lab. Which studies guaranteed income programs across the country.

Sourced Statements: One question the Breathe program raises, Kline said, is what does it mean to have extra money for months versus several years?  “If you knew the money was coming for three years, it’s a much longer runway. Can you go back to school? Can you quit your job now and look for a new one? Can you care for your aging parents?”
Source Justification: director of the Stanford Basic Income Lab. Which studies guaranteed income programs across the country.

Sourced Statements: Every six months, program participants and members in the control group receive the same survey questions about their wellbeing, financially and mentally,  said Amy Castro, director of Penn’s Center for Guaranteed Income Research.
Title of Source: Director, Penn's Center for Guaranteed Income Research
Source Justification: Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania are surveying the 1,000 Breathe participants, along with a control group of people not receiving funds.

Sourced Statements: While there were positive impacts on mental health and wellbeing the first year, when the pandemic broke out, the benefits were less pronounced, according to Penn’s research.
Name of Source: Penn's Center for Guaranteed Income Research
Source Justification: That pilot is one of the only experiments with published study results.

Sourced Statements: Interest nevertheless grew in the last few years as COVID-19 exacerbated income inequality throughout California, researchers said.
Source Justification: https://calmatters.org/california-divide/2022/02/california-income-inequality/

Sourced Statements: Advocates point to the expansion of the federal child tax credit as proof that direct cash payments to families reduce poverty.
Source Justification: In 2021 child poverty decreased to 9% from 17.6% in 2019.

Sourced Statements: Still some opponents said these types of programs discourage participation in the labor market, are too costly and fail to sufficiently reform the welfare system to bring working people out of poverty.
Source Justification: some opponents

Sourced Statements: “There is so much we don’t know yet,” Castro said. “We don’t know how long people need to receive cash to create what level of change.”
Title of Source: Director, Penn's Center for Guaranteed Income Research

Sourced Statements: More than halfway through the Breathe program, Kahlia said she and her business remain a work in progress, but the funds have given her an ability to move forward in a way she hadn’t before.
Source Justification: Kahlia was selected as one of 1,000 participants in L.A. County’s guaranteed income program, called Breathe.

Sourced Statements: “It’s taking me from always putting out fires to being able to actually make some moves to advance, not just being stuck,” Kahlia said.
Source Justification: Kahlia was selected as one of 1,000 participants in L.A. County’s guaranteed income program, called Breathe.

Sourced Statements: “I didn’t expect to be accepted,” to the Breathe program, Kahlia said. “When I was, I was really, really pleasantly surprised. It definitely took the edge off.”
Source Justification: The money came at the perfect time. Because of the pandemic, Kahlia had stopped teaching guitar lessons in person at parks and recreation centers and transitioned to virtual teaching. But one by one, her clients dropped off.

Sourced Statements: Kahlia said she doesn’t keep track of how she spends the Breathe money. A lot of it has gone to health expenses, and some has gone to her business. But she also spends it on day-to-day things like groceries, or a taco night out with friends, she said.
Kahlia thought if she was going to meet clients for her business, showing up in an old, dinged up car wouldn’t do a lot for her image.
Source Justification: Her biggest expense has been a new car she leased after her 28-year-old Toyota Corolla started breaking down.

Sourced Statements: “I’m probably getting more comfortable with spending money,” she said. “Just learning to say yes to stuff. There’s some stuff that, at the beginning of the program I felt was, you know, almost extravagant. And now I’m like ‘Oh my god, I really needed that for my business to move forward.’”
Source Justification: Under other circumstances, Kahlia would have thought twice before spending that money.

Sourced Statements: The lab found, in general, that food and groceries are the top way participants are spending money, making up 35% of the funds spent. Retail sales and services are a close second at 31%.
Source Justification: Though data from the L.A. County guaranteed income program is limited, the Stanford Guaranteed Income Lab tracks 31 pilot programs throughout the country, including the Breathe pilot.

Sourced Statements: Participants also spent the money on transportation (10%) and housing and utilities (8%). They spend a smaller percentage on educational expenses, miscellaneous expenses and health care or medical expenses.
Source Justification: Though data from the L.A. County guaranteed income program is limited, the Stanford Guaranteed Income Lab tracks 31 pilot programs throughout the country, including the Breathe pilot.

Sourced Statements: There’s also anecdotal evidence that participants are spending some on things that may help them build wealth, like starting a business or saving for a down payment on a home, said Brian Arredondo, a coach for program participants.
Source Justification: a coach for program participants.

Sourced Statements: He said participants come to him with a huge variety of needs, from questions about investing and money management to how to find a good mechanic.
Source Justification: Arredondo regularly checks in with about 300 participants.

Sourced Statements: “People need help with normal, everyday interactions that may be easy for some individuals,” he said. “But for others, they don’t have any prior experience with them.”
Source Justification: When Kahlia wanted to lease a new car, she went to Arredondo, who helped her research the used car market. He has helped other participants look for new cars and accompanied them to dealerships.

Sourced Statements: Researchers and advocates stress how no-strings-attached cash not only improves peoples’ financial situations, but gives them peace of mind and improves mental health.
Participants report feeling more free to spend money on self care, outings with family members or sharing their wealth with community members.
It’s those hard-to-measure impacts that are key, said Ely Fournier, who oversees the program coaches at Strength Based Community Change.
Source Justification: who oversees the program coaches at Strength Based Community Change.

Sourced Statements: “It can’t just be the money,” Fournier said. “It’s the opportunity and the access to experiences sometimes that really make a big difference when there is even a little bit more resources folks can have. ”
Source Justification: who oversees the program coaches at Strength Based Community Change.

Sourced Statements: The program funds have given her time, she said.
Source Justification: But she’s made some progress. Normally she’d be stuck in a cycle of teaching guitar lessons to make money, but wouldn’t have time for her business.

Sourced Statements: “I haven’t gotten to the sexy part yet,” Kahlia said. “I had to get stronger and healthier, clear space, and lay a foundation first. Pulling yourself out of a hole often doesn’t look dramatic. For me it’s been the ability to do some fairly tedious stuff over an extended period of time, over and over again.”
Source Justification: Now Kahlia is taking a step back from teaching and spending time writing new arrangements of music to perform for clients. She’s working on updating her website and making calls to potential clients.
